title: Vasilopita - Greek New Years Cake Recipe
description: Vasilopita is a traditional Greek New Year's Day cake served for breakfast. Whoever receives the coin hidden inside gets good luck for the whole year!

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines European Greek Vasilopita - Greek New Years Cake 4.6 (79) 70 Reviews 17 Photos Vasilopita is a Greek cake with a citrus flavor that's not too sweet. It's traditionally served for breakfast or brunch on New Year's Day. Each person gets a slice starting with the youngest — whoever gets the coin hidden in their piece will have good luck for the year! Submitted by Paul Menikos Updated on December 19, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 17 17 17 17 Prep Time: 30 mins Cook Time: 1 hr Total Time: 1 hr 30 mins Servings: 12 Yield: 1 (10-inch) cake Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 12 servings 2 cups white sugar 1 cup butter 3 cups all-purpose flour 6 large eggs 2 teaspoons baking powder 1 cup warm milk (110 degrees F/45 degrees C) ½ teaspoon baking soda 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice ¼ cup blanched slivered almonds 2 tablespoons white sugar Directions Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Generously grease a 10-inch round cake pan. Beat sugar and butter together in a medium bowl until lighter in color; stir in flour and mix until the mixture is mealy. Add eggs one at a time, mixing well after each addition. Combine baking powder and milk; add to egg mixture, mix well. Combine lemon juice and baking soda; stir into the batter. Pour into the prepared cake pan. Bake in the preheated oven for 20 minutes. Remove and sprinkle the nuts and sugar over the cake, then return it to the oven until cake springs back to the touch, about 20 to 30 additional minutes. Gently cut a small hole in the cake and place a quarter in the hole. Try to cover the hole with sugar. Cool cake on a rack for 10 minutes before inverting onto a plate. Serve cake warm. I Made It Print 136 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Vasilopita - Greek New Years Cake 01 of 17 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 17 Photo by  Cece 01/01/2021 03 of 17 Photo by  Madams 12/30/2020 04 of 17 Photo by  Carrie Alvey Connelly 01/06/2020 It was really good! I made it in a Bundt pan. I did need to bake it longer, about 15 minutes. But I didn’t think it was dry, and it was plenty sweet. 05 of 17 Photo by  Kerri1503 01/02/2019 I made this to bring in the new year! I did make a substitute as I didn’t have lemon juice. I added 1 teaspoon of almond extract and topped with powdered sugar. Does need to be naked longer as suggested by others. Delicious! 06 of 17 Photo by  Debra Manitzas Trueman 01/01/2019 Eating a second piece of this cake as I type and WOW is it delicious! My Yaya used to make the New Year's cake for us, so I decided to give it a go. I remembered the cake as being kind of dry and tasteless, so I didn't expect much from this cake, but how wrong I was. This cake is like a pound cake - moist and soooo good. The only change I made was to exchange finely chopped pecans for the almonds because I didn't have almonds. This is a FABULOUS recipe - a keeper that will go into my little book of recipes that I love. Happy New Year 2019!! 07 of 17 Photo by  Emily Lyons 12/30/2018 Its perfect! The only thing I did differently was that I switched the lemon juice with limoncello liqueur. And made a glaze with powdered sugar and the liqueur. 08 of 17 Photo by  Jennifer Bellows 09/30/2018 Very nice! I was trying to make a traditional Spanish "bizcocho" and this recipe reminded me of my mother-in-laws. I like that it's light and not super sweet. Next time I will definitely try it with the slivered almonds. Perfect to enjoy with coffee and family! :) 09 of 17 Photo by  Katina 12/31/2017 10 of 17 Photo by  mitsimac 01/02/2017 It didn't turn out like the picture...it's more yellow because it contains 6 eggs. There was WAY too much batter for one pan and it ended up spilling over into my oven. lol All in all though, nice tasting coffee cake. 1 2 Next You’ll Also Love Honey Cake II 18 Ratings Berry Good Coffee Cake 51 Ratings Raspberry Almond Coffee Cake 402 Ratings Almond Rhubarb Coffee Cake 204 Ratings Aargau Carrot Cake 43 Ratings Bee Sting Cake (Bienenstich) 43 Ratings Easter Simnel Cake 4 Ratings Serano Chocolate Cake 6 Ratings Chocolate Maraschino Cherry Cake 7 Ratings Holiday Bourbon Fruitcake 15 Ratings Kourabiedes 14 Ratings Lemon Polenta Cake 15 Ratings Semolina Cake 5 Ratings Vaselopita 8 Ratings Almond Orange Streusel Coffee Cake 19 Ratings Poppy Seed Cake I 6 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Paul Menikos
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Generously grease a 10-inch round cake pan.;Beat sugar and butter together in a medium bowl until lighter in color; stir in flour and mix until the mixture is mealy. Add eggs one at a time, mixing well after each addition. Combine baking powder and milk; add to egg mixture, mix well. Combine lemon juice and baking soda; stir into the batter. Pour into the prepared cake pan.;Bake in the preheated oven for 20 minutes. Remove and sprinkle the nuts and sugar over the cake, then return it to the oven until cake springs back to the touch, about 20 to 30 additional minutes. Gently cut a small hole in the cake and place a quarter in the hole. Try to cover the hole with sugar. Cool cake on a rack for 10 minutes before inverting onto a plate.;Serve cake warm.
